name.en-us: Certified Construction Manager (CCM) Exam Outline of Competencies

description.en-us: Construction Management Association of America (CMAA) core competencies for construction management (Certified Construction Manager (CCM))

competencyText.en-us: Project Management

Agency CM
Beneficial Occupancy
Bulletin

Direct Costs

The Construction Management Plan
Value Analysis
The purpose and content of the CM Plan
Stating measurable objectives for the project
Methods and standards of measure commonly used to describe projects
Qualitative/performance criteria essential to describe projects
Selecting and prioritizing pertinent reference documents
Summarizing detailed project data for team members
Organization of the project
Understanding relationships between project control systems, procedures and tasks
Types of project organization, decision and authority structures
Understanding organizational structures of other team members
Defining the roles and responsibilities of project team members
Using the “responsibility matrix” to communicate lines of responsibility and authority
Site use planning
Knowledge of construction sequences and operations
Components required for site mobilization/use over project duration
Identifying unique site conditions which may impact construction operations
Alternative or prescriptive sequences to optimize site utilization
Contract administration
Understanding the contractual relationships of team members
Applications of basic contracting/procurement strategies:
Single Prime/Multiple Prime
Lump Sum/Cost Plus/Guaranteed Maximum Price
Design Build
Fast Track
Phased Purchase
Long Lead Procurement
Owner Assignment
Identifying and resolving conflicts duplications or omissions in contractual responsibilities
Developing contract administration and documentation procedures specific to project needs
Analyzing contracting strategies to meet project cost and schedule goals within legal constraints
Quantifying the risks and benefits of alternate contracting strategies
Risk management
Understanding the elements of project design and construction likely to give rise to disputes or claims
General liability risk
Special liability risks
Applying principles and techniques of risk management
Available alternative dispute resolution options
Applicable laws and standards

Purpose and contents
Level of detail appropriate
Project funding
Preparing information required to support owner’s funding requirements (cash flow, budgets, estimates, schedules, program definitions, project descriptions, etc.)
Design Professional Selection
Design resources required to meet specific project requirements
Basic tasks and responsibilities of design professionals
Defining criteria for qualifications and experience of design professionals in relation to the project

The design professional Request for Qualifications/Proposals
Analyzing the fee proposal and distribution

Responsibilities of the parties to a contract
Basic forms of agreement
Basic content requirements of a complete set of contract documents
Sources of risk arising out of design and construction processes
Sources of design efforts and omissions and construction deficiencies leading to construction problems and disputes
Understand degree to which risk can be managed, shifted or insured via construction documents
Insurance requirements and options developed by the owner for the project
Knowledge of basic building materials, systems and construction techniques
Information required for proper coordination of construction processes
Understanding how sequences of construction relate to drawings
Understanding how drawings and various levels of detail or integrated to create a complete depiction of the project

Public relations—means of reaching potential bidders
Assessing bidding climates
Requirements for selection of pre-qualified bidders for bid advertisement
Assessing and evaluating bidder qualifications relative to project requirements
Understanding basic content required of contract general conditions
Addressing risk management issues in contractor’s pre-award meetings

Data requirements to meet reporting goals
Client expectations and requirements
Appropriate levels of detail
Distribution of reports
Procedures for information plan revisions
Providing timely flow of information to the project team
Overall status and forecast of outcome vs. estimate plan
Understanding design report formats
Understanding cost/benefit analyses of various information systems levels
Procedures for retrieval and processing of information
Developing appropriate public relations information
Understand real/perceived impacts of project on the community
Cost Management

Conceptual budgeting methods, components and factors
Interpreting conceptual budgets provided by the owner and assessing impacts on the project cost management plan
Integrating the owner's conceptual budget into the overall cost management plan
Development of a project/construction budget
Project and owner objectives and cost constraints
Procurement strategies, resource availability, productivity and other factors
Site, market, environmental, contingency, escalation and other conditions impacting budget
Cost Management System
Defining the purpose and objectives of a cost management system
Utilizing available resources to develop, coordinate and implement the system
Understanding the concept of cost planning
Need for and utilization of project feasibility studies
Using cost models to monitor cost during progress of design
Cash flow needs and availability based o the project progress schedule
Developing a compatible cash flow schedule
Impact of external economic factors on project cost
Methods of project funding and how they impact project cost and schedule
Estimating
Selection estimating techniques appropriate to the project and its phases
Identifying factors for conceptual estimating
Significance and validity of parameters for cost estimating
Concept of range estimating
Relationship of a quantity survey-based cost estimate to procurement strategies
Applications of quantity surveys to cost estimating
Cost Compliance Monitoring
Defining the objectives of the cot management plan
Developing and implementing a cost monitoring and compliance system utilizing available resources
Specifying cost monitoring methods and frequency of updating, cost tracking and reporting.
Design Phase Cost Management
Estimating the cost and budget impact of design elements
Evaluating design detail and changes and estimating their cost impact on the budget
Establishing effective value analysis program
Alternate systems, methods, components and materials
Trade off factors in terms of first vs. lifetime cost, availability, time of delivery, esthetics, etc.
Construction Phase Cost Management
Specifying cost monitoring and management procedures
Understanding risks of project budgeting and cost analysis efforts
Specifying, developing and implementing an effective schedule o values for prompt and equitable payment requests evaluation
Specifying, developing and implementing an integrated cost-loaded schedule
Developing and implementing and effective change order control and evaluation system
Factors governing cost changes during construction
Specifying, developing and implementing an effective procedure for controlling, analyzing and evaluating cost of potential claims
Cost Control
Utilization of man-hour/cost forecasting productivity studies, impact analysis, efficiency losses, etc.
Bid preparation and review and contract awards
Contracting procedures and types; advantages and constraints

Responsibilities and management structure of project management team

Utilization of reports

Identification of project milestones
Schedule calculations
Forward and backward pass

Early/late dates and float values for activities in a network

Implementing schedule revisions and assessing and minimizing impact on project dates and costs

Defining procedures for management of schedules to avoid risks
Impact of change orders on schedule
Anticipating potential claims for time extensions
Using the schedule to evaluate and mitigate potential claims
Being “claims conscious”
Understanding risks of management of schedules
Understanding how the reporting and document control system interacts with the change order process extensions

Project communications portion of the Project Procedures Manual

Project requirements to be completed prior to final payment
